column2: Income inequality: Gini coefficient (before tax)
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Income share of the top 10% (before tax)
column7: This is the income of the richest 10% as a share of total income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Income inequality: P90/P10 ratio (before tax)
column7: P90 and P10 are the levels of income below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Income inequality: P90/P50 ratio (before tax)
column7: The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Income inequality: P50/P10 ratio (before tax)
column7: The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median income is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Income inequality: Palma ratio (before tax)
column7: The Palma ratio is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Relative poverty: Share of people below 40% of the median income (before tax)
column4: Share in relative poverty (< 40% of the median)
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 40% of the median income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column4: Share in relative poverty (< 50% of the median)
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 50% of the median income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Gini coefficient (Market income, equivalized)
column5:
The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Income share of the richest 10% (Market income, equivalized)
column5:
This is the income of the richest 10% as a share of total income.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: P90/P10 ratio (Market income, equivalized)
column5:
P90 is the the level of income below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: P90/P50 ratio (Market income, equivalized)
column5:
P90 is the the level of income above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: P50/P10 ratio (Market income, equivalized)
column5:
P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Palma ratio (Market income, equivalized)
column5:
The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.

This is market income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: P90/P10 ratio (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5:
P90 is the the level of income below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: P90/P50 ratio (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5:
P90 is the the level of income above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: P50/P10 ratio (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5:
P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Palma ratio (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5:
The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 40% of median income - share of population below poverty line (Disposable household income, equivalized)
column5:
% of population living in households with income below 40% of the median income.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Gini coefficient (Disposable household income, per capita)
column5:
The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Income share of the richest 10% (Disposable household income, per capita)
column5:
This is the income of the richest 10% as a share of total income.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after taxes and social security contributions.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.
